citeinfo.origin: Center for Historical Geography, Fudan University
citeinfo.title: CHGIS China County Capitals, 1911

descript.abstract: This datalayer contains point features which represent the county capitals in China for the year 1911.The CHGIS will establish a database of historical administrative units for different periods in Chinese History, and will also provide a base GIS platform for researchers to use for spatial analysis, temporal statistical modeling, and representation of selected historical units as digital maps.
descript.purpose: Developed by Fudan University, Center for Historical Geography, for the CHGIS project.The CHGIS project is designed to provide a GIS platform for scholarly and scientific research. Considerable flexibility has been designed into the GIS, allowing for alternate versions and variations of feature attributes, spatial data, and competing political entities. The CHGIS aims to build a reliable database of administrative units, but does not wish to impose a closed interpretation on the relationships among those units. The advantage of creating the CHGIS, rather than printing paper maps, is that the relationships between the units can be modified and improved whenever new information becomes available and the new "edition" needs only to be posted on the Internet for users to download. The CHGIS editors have set high editorial standards for the inclusion of material in the CHGIS data products and regulate the release of the official versions from designated CHGIS participating organizations.Users may search the database for settlements, administrative units and capitals, can create customized digital maps for particular times and places, or can join their own datasets for spatial anaysis, thematic mapping, or other specialized statistical modeling according to their own interests.
descript.supplinf: The names of populated places in the CHGIS dataset are represented by both Chinese characters and Pinyin. Chinese characters may not display properly on machines without the proper character sets installed.UTF-8 Encoding is employed for Chinese characters.

idinfo.accconst: The CHGIS datasets are freely distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes. The datasets may be obtained by ordering a CD-ROM or downloaded free of charge from the CHGIS website.Please consult the website (http://fas.harvard.edu/~chgis) for additional details.
idinfo.useconst: Academic use of CHGIS data is allowed, and encouraged, provided that any derived data or digital images of maps give proper citation to CHGIS as stated above. The CHGIS datasets are distributed for non-commercial academic research purposes only. Any organization or individual that makes commercial or revenue generating use of the CHGIS Datasets must first obtain a licensing agreement from CHGIS Management Committee. Use of the datasets distributed on CD-ROM or downloaded from CHGIS websites implies acceptance of all the terms stated in the End User's License Agreement, and acknowledges understanding of any liabilities stated therein by the end-user.

cntinfo.hours: Monday through Friday 9:00 A.M. to 4:00 P.M. EST-USA

idinfo.datacred: CHGIS, Version: 2.0. Cambridge, MA (USA): Harvard Yenching Institute, April 2002 (Revised August, 2003)
idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows NT Version 4.0 (Build 1381) Service Pack 6; ESRI ArcCatalog 8.2.0.700

dataqual.complete: The project begins with the publication of CHGIS Version 1.0, which contains datasets for the year 1820 (Qing Dynasty). Version 2.0 was published in August, 2003. Following this release, the project will work backwards, creating a continuous time series of records that track changes in placename, administrative status, and geography.

horizpa.horizpar: Numerous points lacked sufficient evidence to snap them to the DMDC locations, and these were simply left alone (with possible location errors as a legacy of the digitization from Tan's "Historical Atlas of China"). However, all such points are indicated as having derived their location FROM_TAN in the GEO_SRC field, and in many cases were nudged into their most probable locations based on the hydrography and digitial elevation basemap materials that were also used for contextual reference.

srcinfo.srccontr: The national level CHGIS datasets for the year 1911 are based on materials that were used in the production of the "Historical Atlas of China," Volume 8 (1987) edited by Tan Qixiang. The national boundaries strictly follow those shown in the Tan's Atlas, while some of the settlement points (called "populated places") as well as polylines representing prefecture borders and rivers have been edited to reflect evidence in historical sources and to properly mesh with the correct positions of natural features.

citeinfo.origin: National Bureau of Surveying and Mapping (NBSM)
citeinfo.title: 1:1,000,000 Scale Topographic Map of China (Digital Map Database of China)

pubinfo.publish: National Bureau of Surveying and Mapping (NBSM)

citeinfo.othercit: Each map sheet covers six degrees longitude by four degrees latitude.The 1:1,000,000-scale map series is the smallest National Essential Topographic Map Series in China, which comprehensively depicts the natural, social and economic situation in China and forms a relevant geographic base for many uses.

srcinfo.srccontr: Used for the authoritative basemap for comparison of historical data and rectification.

procstep.procdesc: Base Map To begin the examination of spatial changes over time, a base map is prepared for the selected target area (usually a single county or prefecture). The base map includes three contemporary layers circa 1990: Digital Map Database of China (DMDC) county boundaries; DMDC towns and administrative unit points; DMDC rivers and one newly developed historical layer (CHGIS 1911 county boundaries). The 1911 county boundaries are used as the primary reference for reconstructing the historical boundaries. The base maps are printed out on A3 size paper. Draft Version of Historical Maps Researchers use cross-hatch patterns and different colored pens to compile space-time-composite polygons directly on the base map. In some cases a section of the historical boundary line is judged to coincide with the 1911 or the 1990 boundary line, in other cases a new line is drawn directly on the base map to indicate the valid boundary for a particular period of time. The color coded patterns are dated and annotated alongside the sketch, directly on the base map. Each county or prefecture area is traced backwards in time using this method. Historical Point Locations Historical towns and administrative seats are determined using a similar method as the historical areas, sometimes on the same base map sheet as the areas, sometimes on a separate sheet. For historical points, the place names and their valid dates are written directly onto the base map. For each location, such as an administrative seat for a prefecture, the base map is examined to see if the correct location is now occupied by a contemporary point feature in the DMDC layer (circa 1990). If the historical point is located exactly at the same position as the DMDC feature, the DMDC point is marked with a colored pen and labeled with the historical name and dates of validity. If a matching position in DMDC is not available, the historical location is estimated based on the relative context of the DMDC points, boundaries, rivers and the 1911 boundaries. When establishing the location of historical points that cannot be "snapped" directly to existing DMDC features, many historical sources including maps, gazetteers, and secondary sources are consulted. Having established the best estimate for the location of a particular historical point, the point is added with a colored pen and labeled with the historical point's name and dates. The resulting base map contains a number of colored points with labels indicating the placename and the begin and end dates for which that name and location were valid. Compilation of the 1911 County Boundaries One of the GIS layers used for the base maps contains 1911 county boundary lines. The method of compiling the 1911 county boundaries is both complex and illustrative of how the historical areas of jurisdiction are determined. The basic idea involves the addition of points to the CHGIS datasets, based on their existence in a particular county level jurisdiction in 1911. By judging which historical jurisdiction those points lie within, an approximate boundary line including those points can be drawn. The original maps produced in 1911 were not drawn to exact scale or known projection, but were created using a surveying and calculation technique which varied from region to region. Because of the scale and projection anomalies it is not possible to use the "rubber-sheeting" method to digitize the maps into GIS. Rubber-sheeting is the process of stretching and skewing a scanned digital image of a map so that a sampling of particular locations on the map match their correct positions in a known projection. Rather than scanning and rubber-sheeting the 1911 maps, the original maps, are consulted alongside the GIS workstation. For sections of the 1911 boundary which are determined to be the same as 1990 boundary lines, those line sections are digitized by copying the existing arc segment to a new GIS layer. Similarly some of the historical boundary sections can be matched to sections of rivers, and these river arc segments are copied to the new layer. For parts of the border which do not correspond directly to the 1990 boundaries or the river lines, the points shown as lying within the jurisdiction of the 1911 county are carefully noted and compared with contemporary points. Many of these points can be snapped to their contemporary 1990 positions. Once the points known to have been part of the 1911 county have been digitized into the GIS layers, the remaining boundary sections encompassing those points can be drawn. The finished 1911 county boundary line will therefore include information derived in at least three ways: from line sections that exactly match 1990 county boundary line sections; from line sections that exactly match river line sections; from newly drawn line sections that contain known constituent towns for the year 1911.
The CHGIS shapefile was imported to an ArcSDE Layer.

attr.attrdef: Date from which the instance, either established for the first time, or subsequent to a change from a previous instance, begins to be valid.
Codes defining rules for establishing Begin Date

edom.edomvd: Year is set according to a pan-Dynastic period, such as "Qin Han," or " Song Yuan"
Year is set according to a Dynastic period, such as "Tang," or " Ming"
Year is set according to a Dynastic Title or Reign Period, such as "Shundi," or "Zhizheng"
Year is specified, such as "13th Year of the Kangxi Reign Period"
Season or Month is specified, such as "4th month of the Lunar year," or "autumn"
Date is specified, such as "jiachen day, 5th month, 14th Year of the Jiaqing Reign Period"
Date is precise and based on a known year

attr.attrdef: Date when the instance ceases to be valid, either because of another change or because the historical place ceases to exist.
Codes defining rules for establishing End Date
